awd_titl_txt: Direct Chemical Kinetics Studies of Elusive Intermediates in Combustion: Ketohydroperoxides
awd_abstract_narration:
The development of sustainable energy technologies for transportation remains a significant scientific challenge and a high priority for the United States and rest of the world. Given the current and projected reliance on combustion-derived energy for decades to come, a key challenge is increasing the efficiency of next-generation combustion systems. Improvements in efficiency relies on better understanding of chemical reactions that control ignition and heat-release processes in engines. Both are important in optimizing predictive models used to simulate combustion chemistry. Importantly, the efficacy of such models hinges on validation against detailed experimental data. Therefore, the primary activity of the research herein is the study of elementary chemical reactions from a previously unstudied set of molecules, ketohydroperoxides, which are elusive intermediates and central to understanding ignition process. The primary benefit of the present research is the development of new fundamental understanding of chemical reaction pathways and rates relevant to combustion as well as new modeling capabilities to improve the robustness of existing computer simulation models. In addition, the research project encompasses scientific training of Ph.D. students and undergraduate Student Veterans, as well as augmentation of local high school-level educational materials related to sustainable transportation energy. 

The research herein addresses the knowledge gap on the connection between the molecular structure of intermediate species ketohydroperoxides and products formation during combustion. To achieve this objective, an interdisciplinary team with expertise in chemical synthesis of ketohydroperoxides, derived from cyclohexane combustion, and physical chemistry is formed. Reactions of the three isomer species are studied using two different experiments: multiplexed photoionization mass spectrometry at the Advanced Light Source synchrotron, and speciation from a high-pressure jet-stirred reactor at the University of Georgia. In parallel to experiments, Reaction Mechanism Generator software package is used to generate a new sub-mechanisms for cyclohexane combustion chemistry. The impetus for the present modelling work is that unimolecular decomposition reactions are the only consumption pathways of ketohydroperoxide species in current combustion models. However, other reaction pathways common to alkylperoxy radicals are possible, including reaction with hydroxyl radicals and with oxygen. With complete characterization of reaction pathways, the existing uncertainties of chemical kinetics models can be minimized with accurate predictions of combustion efficiency.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

inst.inst_name: University of Georgia Research Foundation Inc
inst.org_lgl_bus_name: UNIVERSITY OF GEORGIA RESEARCH FOUNDATION, INC.

por.por_cntn:
This project accomplished the first syntheses of ketohydroperoxide (KHP) species derived from cyclohexane and n-butane, which are two prototypical hydrocarbons relevant constituent species in practical transportation fuels. The chemical synthesis portion of this project was complemented with two supporting types of characterization experiments to (i) confirm the molecular structure of the target species and (ii) ensure the synthesized chemicals were produced in sufficiently high concentrations to enable gas-phase combustion experiments to be conducted.

First, multiplexed photoionization mass spectrometry (MPIMS) experiments were conducted at the Advanced Light Source synchrotron. These measurements were conducted on 4-hydroperoxycyclohexan-1-one and published in Ke et al. (“Multigram Synthesis of a Combustion-Relevant delta-Ketohydroperoxide via Sulfonylhydrazine Substitution”, Chemistry - A European Journal, 2022) along with a detailed description of the chemical synthesis routes. Second, to enable jet-stirred reactor (JSR) experiments at the University of Georgia, mass spectrometry and VUV-absorption spectroscopy measurements were conducted on KHP species produced from the chemical synthesis portion of the project. These latter measurements provided confirmation on acyclic KHP species produced via n-butane oxidation. Through interdisciplinary, collaborative science, the project produced a thorough knowledge base to foster continued progress on KHP species, which are a highly elusive class of molecules that require novel synthesis strategies, such as those employed here, in order to study directly and in a quantitative manner.

The intellectual merit of this project is the knowledge gap filled concerning the ability to produce KHP species via novel organic synthesis methods to enable direct experimental studies that reveal connections between the molecular structure of, and product formation from reactions of KHP species and related impact on the fidelity of combustion models. KHP species are an elusive class of molecules to which combustion models show appreciable sensitivity, largely due to ambiguity surrounding the chemical reaction pathways unfolding in the gas phase at combustion conditions. The experimental portions of the project were complemented with model development efforts using Reaction Mechanism Generator (RMG) to produce unique sub-mechanisms that are useful to include in combustion models.

The project involved broader impacts useful to several scientific areas by providing novel pathways to enable the experimental study of KHP species for purposes of autoignition chemistry relevant to combustion, atmospheric studies of autoxidation reactions of volatile organic compounds, and advanced engine strategies design such as gasoline-direct-injection (GDI). In addition, because of the tendency of KHP to form small organic acids and carbonyls via the Korcek mechanism, the synthesis procedures reported from this project enable experimental studies to reveal insight on exhaust composition for catalysis design in low-temperature combustion engines, where quantifying the array of gas-phase species entering the catalytic converter is an important parameter.

Direct educational benefits from this work included augmenting local high school-level material related to sustainable transportation energy achieved through collaboration with SciREN, an outreach program the PI is involved with that connects local educators with universities to foster the dissemination of current research topics to enhance the science literacy of middle school and high school students. The work directly involved research training of undergraduate student veterans, which is important because student veterans are underrepresented at major, research-intensive universities.

 


Last Modified: 07/30/2024
Modified by: Brandon Rotavera
